He aint top 10 but he is top 20 though here is my personal top 20 all time: 1. Marlon Brando 2. Al Pacino 3. Daniel Day-Lewis 4. Jack Nicholson 5. Robert De Niro 6. Laurence Olivier 7. Leonardo DiCaprio 8. Tom Hanks 9. Dustin Hoffman 10. Paul Newman 11. Denzel Washington 12. Sidney Poitier 13. Anthony Hopkins 14. James Stewart 15. Gary Oldman 16. Spencer Tracy 17. Morgan Freeman 18. Michael Caine 19. Peter O'Toole 20. Philip Seymour Hoffman

Â @ishfarahmed3684Â  The list seems perfect. I agree with you. Brando at the top is obvious. Followed by Al Pacino, Nicholson etc. Al Pacino is a greater method actor compared to Nicholson. And Laurence Olivier even though a great actor who could enunciate the works of Shakespeare with perfection, isn't as good as many of the method actors before him in your list. Tom Hanks is my most favorite actor, but he's definitely not the best. Also it makes sense to place Denzel Washington lower. He's a great actor, but not as great as the one mentioned before him. Spencer Tracy, James Stewart lived in an Era were  actors performed theatrically even in Cinema. Their performances, even though good weren't like really natural. I've noticed this from his collaborations with Hitchcock and the movie It's a Wonderful Life. Anthony Hopkins is a great actor. But it's one performance that made him stand out among so many others. I guess we both know which film that is. Paul Newman's a good actor. I've loved his performances in movies like Cool Hand Like, The Color Money, A Cat on A Hot Tin Roof etc. Philip Seymour never got to show us more of what he had since he passed away at an early age.

It happens to everybody on the public forum, internet or not. There's an entire industry that literally psychologically breaks celebrities down for the dumbest bullshit imaginable and it leaks onto you local TV News. So it's everywhere unfortunately and there are far far worse going on than someone writing "fuck you" on twitter. There is another side to it though, some people legitimately do find it funny. It isn't black and white.

I don't think it's as clear as us sharing in on the insult. In fact, I respect a lot of these celebrities and when I hear these things I'm actually flabbergasted that there are people out there that dislike them so much. In a way, it shows that we're all more alike than we think - there will be ppl who won't like us even when we're good, and the person writing them might not be right anyway. It just shows how varied opinions can be. This discussion is a testament to that. I understand that some of the celebs look hurt, and that makes me sad, but by watching, I feel for them and want to help them up. So the insult can have an opposite effect, and I wouldn't be surprised if that's the reason for this segment - most of the insults are absurd which diminishes the comment as a result!

Cam Maida lots of things are possible, but everything we observe about the universe from here tells us that the rules of the universe are the same everywhere. That things can't go from point A to point B without actually traveling between those points. That energy spreads out and weakens as it spreads out. That things are either in one place or they are spread out. All the things people like to believe about the gods that we have invented here on earth are just fantasies. When we were children, we all imagined things like flying, or teleportation, or wishes that could come true. But when you grow up, you're supposed to forget about things like that and learn to live in reality and accept things the way they are. Anything is possible, but the stories that people told themselves thousands of years ago about powerful beings that lived in the sky or at the top of the mountain or wherever are clearly just that: stories. Jehovah is no more likely to be true then is Thor or Zeus or Osiris or any other. Christianity is very widespread, but that's largely because people who didn't accept Christianity were murdered hundreds of years ago. That doesn't make it any more likely that Jehovah is real. If there is something much more powerful than us somewhere out there, it probably won't resemble in any way the things described in the Bible. Why would they? The Bible was written by men who didn't have any magical source of knowledge about anything, any more than the ancient Greeks, or the ancient Norse, or the ancient Egyptians.

Fredde, a British accent doesn't exist. Britain is comprised of 4 countries: England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland. And within each country, there are a variety of accents. FreddeÂ I'm Canadian. And I understand that many people say "British" accent. But most people use the word British to mean English (from England), but it's not a synonym. You wouldn't say British to mean Scottish, Irish or Welsh normally. And unfortunately it shows one's ignorance (not YOU specifically, but everyone who uses the term). We don't know what we don't know, right? So I thought I'd mention it in case you were willing to learn something new. Many people would take offence since accents are actually very distinct. It's like telling a Canadian or Mexican they have an American accent. We are from the Americas, so we are American... but we're not from the United States (which calls itself and is known as America, which is a whole other topic of conversation). Just as if you (assuming you are from the U.S.) might be put off if you were told you have a Canadian accent because it's all part of the Americas, and it's all the same, right? You, too, might take offence. Maybe. And this note certainly is not meant to offend you in any way, just sharing a wider perspective on the subject. If you don't care... no worries. If it helps, then great.

Notta FoxÂ You've draw a distinction between hating what a person does or has done, and hating them on a personal level, but when you hate someone on a personal level, you generally still hate them based on how they act. So if Â you strongly dislike two different people, both based on their actions, and you happen to have personally met one but not the other, it seems fairly arbitrary to say that you can only hate the one you've personally met. You dislike them both equally based on the same considerations; the way they act. You might say that the difference is that your information about the person you've never met may be inaccurate or incomplete in an important respect, but that's a possibility not a certainty and you could also be wrong about someone you have met anyway. Channing KariÂ the PUNCTUATION didn't imply anything other than a question because the sentece ended with a question mark (?). But I will agree that the sentence structure did imply an affirmative sentence. Still, it is possible to pose a question like this and that is why she read it wrong.
LelekPLÂ You can't make your own rules when writing English. Oh wait, yeah it's the Internet where illiterate people lurk everywhere!

Bang MiÂ What own rules are you speaking of? The sentence ended with a question mark, hence she should have used a rising intonation. It's as simple as that. The sentence structure was affiramtive however in everyday use people often can add rising intonation to an affirmative statement to ask for a confirmation.

Channing KariÂ What are you even talking about? What "first punctuation!? The only punctuation in this sentence is a question mark! English is not Spanish and you don't have a question mark at the beginning of an interrogative sentence.

Channing KariÂ  The exclamation mark (!)? It is often used with a question mark to emphasize something, in this case to emphasize the writers disbelief. There's no rule as to which punctuation mark is prevelant in this sentence since it's not a real grammatical rule. It's only used in everyday, casual writing.
LelekPLÂ But there's no such sentence that ends with two punctuations! haha it only exists on the internet like this!!!!!!!!!!?????????!!! AHAHAHA  #IDIOT Â

Bang Mi That's exactly what I said. EXACTLY. It's not a grammatical rule! There is no rule as to which of them is dominant because it's not grammatical...So before you start calling people idiots, maybe try reading more clearly.  However you saying it's used only on the Internet is also very wrong. It's used in many sources, especially artistic, to more adequately express the disbelief of the author. It's nothing new or strange and even if not determined by any grammatical rule, its message is still clear and obvious. ESPECIALLY since a question mark expresses a rising intonation. It's as simple as that.
